articles.headline: U.S. Is Exploring Talks With Iran on Crisis in Iraq
articles.snippet: The United States sees potential meetings with Iran as an opportunity to discuss the threat posed by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Sunni extremist group.
articles.abstract: The United States sees potential meetings with Iran as an opportunity to discuss the threat posed by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Sunni extremist group.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior American diplomat met with his Iranian counterpart in Vienna on Monday to explore whether the United States and Iran could work together to create a more stable Iraqi government and ease the threat from Sunni militants.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: In Another Blow, G.M. Recalls 3 Million More Defective Cars
articles.snippet: Keys with extra weight could cause the vehicles to switch off in a “jarring event,” and will need modification on several models, the automaker says.
articles.abstract: Keys with extra weight could cause the vehicles to switch off in a “jarring event,” and will need modification on several models, the automaker says.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Monday that it would recall 3.36 million defective cars worldwide, another low point in the seemingly endless safety crisis that has engulfed the nation’s largest automaker.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: In Medtronic’s Deal for Covidien, an Emphasis on Tax Savings
articles.snippet: The medical device company will reincorporate in Ireland as part of its merger with Covidien.
articles.abstract: The medical device company will reincorporate in Ireland as part of its merger with Covidien.
articles.lead_paragraph: To invest in the United States, Medtronic says it needs to move to Ireland.

articles.headline: Truckers Resist Rules on Sleep, Despite Risks of Drowsy Driving
articles.snippet: Drowsy driving, a leading cause of crashes and highway fatalities, has come to the fore after an accident involving the comedian Tracy Morgan on a stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike.
articles.abstract: Drowsy driving, a leading cause of crashes and highway fatalities, has come to the fore after an accident involving the comedian Tracy Morgan on a stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tractor-trailer set off at 2:30 a.m. from Springfield, Mo., the usual time and place. Nearly 11 hours later, along the Will Rogers Turnpike in Oklahoma, fatigue caught up.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Elizabeth A. Harris

articles.headline: Study Asserts Startling Numbers of Insider Trading Rogues
articles.snippet: Two professors have evidence of what we’ve long suspected: Insider trading is far more common than the number of prosecutions would suggest, arising from perhaps a quarter of all public company deals.
articles.abstract: Two professors have evidence of what we’ve long suspected: Insider trading is far more common than the number of prosecutions would suggest, arising from perhaps a quarter of all public company deals.

articles.headline: Sunnis and Kurds on Sidelines of Iraqi Leader’s Military Plans
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has resisted calls to work with Sunni Arabs and Kurds, instead spending most of his time running his country’s military strategy and trying to recruit Shiites to battle separatists.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has resisted calls to work with Sunni Arabs and Kurds, instead spending most of his time running his country’s military strategy and trying to recruit Shiites to battle separatists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has presented himself as the man who could bring Iraqis together, but with the collapse of his army before a Sunni militant assault, he has taken on only one role — that of commander in chief of Iraq.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: Migrants Flow in South Texas, as Do Rumors
articles.snippet: Talk of “permits” allowing migrants who crossed the border illegally to stay temporarily in the United States has added to a surge of families arriving from Central America.
articles.abstract: Talk of “permits” allowing migrants who crossed the border illegally to stay temporarily in the United States has added to a surge of families arriving from Central America.
articles.lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex. — Exhausted and dazed, hundreds of Central American migrants, mainly women with small children, come to the bus station of this border city every day now, spilling into a church next door that has opened its doors. Having crossed into the United States illegally, the new arrivals are often grimy and famished. In the church, they eat, bathe and sleep, changing into donated shoes and clothes.

articles.headline: A Bolder Effort by Big Tobacco on E-Cigarettes
articles.snippet: Big Tobacco is moving to turn the e-cigarette market to its advantage, with subsidiaries of the companies that make Marlboro and Camel set to announce nationwide marketing plans.
articles.abstract: Big Tobacco is moving to turn the e-cigarette market to its advantage, with subsidiaries of the companies that make Marlboro and Camel set to announce nationwide marketing plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Electronic cigarettes, promoted as a healthier alternative to tobacco, are getting powerful new backers with an unhealthy reputation: big tobacco companies.

articles.headline: As Sunnis Die in Iraq, a Cycle Is Restarting
articles.snippet: Many Iraqis said they feared a resumption of the sectarian violence that occurred during the height of the 2006-08 war.
articles.abstract: Many Iraqis said they feared a resumption of the sectarian violence that occurred during the height of the 2006-08 war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As Sunni militants rampaged across northern Iraq last week, executing Iraqi soldiers and government workers and threatening to demolish Shiism’s most sacred shrines, Iraq’s Shiites suffered mostly in silence, maintaining a patience urged on them by their religious leaders through months of deadly bombings.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: U.S. Seizure of Suspect in 2012 Benghazi Assault Ends Long Manhunt
articles.snippet: Commandos and F.B.I. agents descended on the outskirts of Benghazi just after midnight local time on Monday; grabbed Ahmed Abu Khattala, the suspect; and raced away, said those briefed on the operation.
articles.abstract: Commandos and F.B.I. agents descended on the outskirts of Benghazi just after midnight local time on Monday; grabbed Ahmed Abu Khattala, the suspect; and raced away, said those briefed on the operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American commandos operating under the cover of night seized the man suspected of leading the deadly attack on the United States Mission in Benghazi, Libya, the government announced on Tuesday, ending a manhunt that had dragged on for nearly two years and inflamed domestic and international politics.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Peter Baker and Eric Schmitt
